skill.name: when-managing-multiple-repos-use-github-multi-repo
skill.description: Multi-repository coordination, synchronization, and architecture management with AI swarm orchestration. Coordinates repo-architect, code-analyzer, and coordinator agents across multiple repositories to maintain consistency, propagate changes, manage dependencies, and ensure architectural alignment. Handles monorepo-to-multi-repo migrations, cross-repo refactoring, and synchronized releases. Use when managing microservices, multi-package ecosystems, or coordinating changes across related repositories.
skill.summary: Multi-repository coordination, synchronization, and architecture management with AI swarm orchestrat...
skill.author: DNYoussef

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing standard operating procedures for multi-repository GitHub management. No executable code, no scripts, no sensitive data access. All static findings are false positives from the analyzer misinterpreting documentation examples as executable code. MCP tools handle actual GitHub operations based on user permissions.

content.value_statement: Managing changes across multiple repositories is complex and error-prone. This skill orchestrates AI agents to propagate updates, enforce architecture, and synchronize releases across all repositories consistently.
actual_capabilities: Propagate changes across multiple repositories with dependency awareness
Migrate monorepos to multi-repo structure while preserving Git history
Enforce consistent architectural patterns across all repositories
Coordinate synchronized releases across dependent repositories
Analyze repository dependencies and identify impact scope
Manage CI/CD pipelines for multi-repo environments
limitations: Requires GitHub access and appropriate repository permissions
Scripts referenced in documentation must exist in user environment
Cannot create new repositories without GitHub API credentials
Depends on claude-flow and flow-nexus MCP tools for orchestration

use_cases.title: Microservices Orchestration
use_cases.description: Manage dozens of microservices across separate repositories with consistent architecture and coordinated deployments.

use_cases.title: Cross-Repo Change Propagation
use_cases.description: Update shared libraries and propagate breaking changes to all dependent repositories automatically.

use_cases.title: Monorepo Migration
use_cases.description: Split a monolithic repository into focused repositories while preserving full Git history and commit provenance.

prompt_templates.title: Quick Propagation
prompt_templates.prompt: Propagate a breaking change to our shared authentication library across all consumer services. Use hierarchical coordinator to identify affected repos and sequence updates.

prompt_templates.title: Migration Planning
prompt_templates.prompt: Analyze our monorepo and create a migration plan to split it into separate repositories. Include dependency analysis and history preservation strategy.

prompt_templates.title: Architecture Audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Scan all our repositories for architectural compliance. Use code-analyzer to identify violations and create a prioritized remediation plan.

prompt_templates.title: Release Coordination
prompt_templates.prompt: Coordinate a synchronized release across all repositories in our microservices ecosystem. Create PRs, run tests, and merge in dependency order.

output_examples.input: Propagate our new API response format to all services that consume the user API
output: Identified 5 affected repositories via dependency graph
Hierarchical coordinator created update sequence
Worker agents spawned for parallel updates
Integration tests validated across all repos
Draft PRs created in all 5 repositories
Merge sequence planned with API library first
Coordinated release scheduled after CI passes

output_examples.input: Migrate our monorepo to separate frontend and backend repositories
output: Analyzed monorepo structure and module boundaries
Identified cross-cutting dependencies requiring refactoring
Created split strategy preserving Git history
Extracted frontend code with full commit provenance
Extracted backend code with full commit provenance
Generated refactoring plan for shared utilities
Validated both repositories build independently

output_examples.input: Enforce our new naming conventions across all team repositories
output: Cloned all 12 team repositories
Ran architectural linting against naming rules
Generated compliance report for each repository
Found 47 violations across 8 repositories
Created automated fixes for common violations
Generated draft PRs with naming convention updates
Prioritized remediation by violation severity

best_practices: Always initialize hierarchical swarm with a coordinator for consistent decision-making
Respect dependency order when applying changes to avoid build breaks
Test repositories together after multi-repo changes since individual tests may pass while integration fails
anti_patterns: Running parallel updates without checking dependency relationships
Merging consumer repositories before upstream dependencies are released
Skipping integration tests when each repository passes individually

faq.question: What AI tools support this skill?
faq.answer: Claude Code and Claude Code CLI are supported. The skill uses MCP tools for GitHub integration.

faq.question: How many repositories can it manage?
faq.answer: Scales from small coordination (2-5 repos) to large orchestration (10+ repositories) with adaptive agent spawning.

faq.question: Does it integrate with existing CI/CD?
faq.answer: Yes. Uses scripts for orchestration and can trigger existing CI/CD pipelines in each repository.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Safe. Documentation-only skill with no external network calls. MCP tools access GitHub based on user permissions.

faq.question: Scripts are missing from the skill
faq.answer: The skill references scripts that should exist in the user environment. Scripts handle actual git operations and API calls.

faq.question: How is this different from GitHub Actions?
faq.answer: GitHub Actions runs per-repository. This skill coordinates across repositories with AI agents that understand dependencies.
